awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Low Cost Desktop Learning Modules to Educate Diverse Undergraduate Communities in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a collaboration between Washington State University and Campbell University that aims to expand the use of desktop learning modules to create more experiential, effective, and engaging hands-on interactive learning environments for educating engineers. The project will develop lab units called Desktop Learning Modules, which are hands-on miniaturized equipment representing real  industrial processes. They are portable, can be used outside of class, and significantly assist students in learning about fluid mechanics and heat transfer, both of which are fundamental transport concepts in engineering. The goal of the project is to transform teaching and learning in foundational engineering courses through national dissemination of fluid mechanics and heat transfer Desktop Learning Modules. Training workshops and community development will be provided through five regional hubs to be established to help disseminate the Desktop Learning Module approach.

Prior use of hydraulics Desktop Learning Modules have shown that 70% of students achieved competency on concepts tested, on average, compared to 39% in control groups. Also, in fluid mechanics, participants have shown significant learning gains. In preliminary studies, the transferability of Desktop Learning Modules to other institutions has been demonstrated.  For example, after using a Desktop Learning Module, the University of Kentucky observed a 50-100% improvement in post-tests on topics such as hydraulic loss. In this project, a mixed methods research study will be used to test the hypothesis that definitive changes can occur in student learning and interest when Desktop Learning Modules are used in a team-oriented, hands-on learning environment. A faculty support framework will be used to foster changes in engagement with the novel pedagogy, thus enhancing instructor ease of adoption and implementation. It is expected that the project will have significant impact on the learning of difficult engineering concepts and increase diversity in engineering by accommodating of a range of student abilities and learning preferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded IUSE project Collaborative Research: Using Low Cost Desktop Learning Modules (LC-DLMs) to Educate Diverse Undergraduate Communities in Engineering spanned six years including 2020 and the duration of the COVID-19 pandemic. This project aimed to manufacture, disseminate, and implement small scaled thermal-fluids equipment – LC-DLMs to undergraduate engineering classrooms across the United States. We recruited professors, trained them on how to use the LC-DLMs in the classroom, and equipped them with worksheets and units to train their students. New knowledge was gained by testing if the LC-DLMs in a non-local environment across different universities and professors. PIs collected survey data on cognitive and motivational gains in mechanical and chemical engineering students.

Six years later, we have made incredible progress. Four LC-DLMs have been manufactured and disseminated and two more have been designed and manufactured for select implementations. About ~200 each hydraulic loss units, venturi units, shell and tube heat exchangers, and double pipe heat exchangers have been sent to thirty-one institutions of higher education across the United States. Fifty-one professors across these institutions have implemented the modules, and 4,305 students have used the units to gain knowledge on thermal-fluids concepts. Individually, there have been 70 hydraulic loss implementations, 76 for the venturi meter, 60 for the double pipe, and 45 for the shell and tube.

Two additional units were designed, tested, manufactured, and implemented in the undergraduate classroom. A fluidized bed had one implementation at Washington State University with 23 students and 23 students used an evaporative cooler at Washington State University and the University of Dayton.

Because of the onset of COVID-19 in 2020, we have also developed a YouTube channel with a series of 18 demonstration and conceptual thermal-fluid videos for virtual implementations. These videos have over 18,400 views, a total watch time of 699 hours, and 153 subscribers. Of note, the majority of views occurred outside the United States.

Throughout the project, students took surveys after using the units to measure cognitive and motivational gains. The fluidized beds modules whereby the pressure could be immediately viewed by the students via monometers showed immense gains in cognitive retention among students. All four modules increased students’ motivation and make them feel like they better learned the thermal-fluids concepts associated with the in-class activities.
